awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC Phase II Renewal: Center for Visual and Decision Informatics (CVDI)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will help the University of Louisiana at Lafayette transition its IUCRC Center for Visual and Decision Informatics (CVDI) into Phase 2 operation for the next 5 years. At the start of Phase 2, the CVDI IUCRC is expanding from three sites to 5 sites, with the addition of two new sites, and University of Louisiana at Lafayette will serve as the managing lead site of the Center for this phase. The Center seeks to continue its record of sustained accomplishments in terms of strengthening and growing industry partnerships, delivering innovation through intellectual property and publications, expanding research competencies through increased faculty participation, and broadening educational experience of students through participation in industry funded research.

The research program of the Center focuses on developing next-generation visual and decision support tools and techniques that enable decision makers to fundamentally improve the way an organization's information is interpreted and exploited. CVDI's area of research is industry-relevant, attracts membership and has the potential to improve US competitiveness in this area. The center intends to broaden participation through center engagement in university programs. Through participation in the Louis Stokes Louisiana Alliance for Minority Participation Program, of which the PI is the co-coordinator, this site will introduce undergraduate minority students to industry-driven research. CVDI will recruit students from neighboring Historically Black Colleges and Universities to join our graduate programs. The site will also participate in university outreach programs for K-12 students, such as the annual Engineering and Technology Expo Week and the Science Day.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Over the past decade, the exponential growth in digital data has significantly challenged organizations, both in managing large datasets and extracting valuable insights from them. The NSF Center for Visual and Decision Informatics, which evolved to phase II in 2012, grew to be the largest active I/UCRC (Industry/University Cooperative Research Center) within the Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE) directorate. The Center had five major university partners in the United States and a few Finnish universities through its international partnership with Tampere University in Finland. The Center's establishment in Louisiana marked a milestone as the first in the state. Its impact on industry partners in various ways, including to students, faculty members and broader university communities, has been significant.

The Center has facilitated knowledge exchange, research collaboration, and technological advancements. Through its initiatives, it has fostered the growth of students, supported faculty research endeavors, and empowered industry partners with valuable insights and solutions. The center's contributions have accelerated innovation and promoted data-driven decision-making within the region and beyond. Specifically, CVDI comprised 68 research faculty members who worked on a wide range of significant data-related challenges, leading to the successful completion of 94 IAB-funded projects, producing 42 invention disclosures, 2 licensing agreements, and 27 patent applications, and receiving $11M in research funding. The research conducted by CVDI made a significant impact on 134 students who were involved in the projects, and it resulted in the generation of 169 publications showcasing the outcomes and findings of the research.

Notable projects include (a) Solutions developed to “Missing Data and System Failure Challenges in Edge-based Machine Learning”, applicable to domains like intelligent buildings, public safety, and vehicular computing, which were adopted by Haltian and Tieto in their empathic building program, (b) “The Big Data Optimization Tool”, developed for and utilized by CGI Federal, enhanced computational performance of flood forecasting for early warning systems and traffic management, (c) The project, “Real-world Study on Stress Detection during COVID-19” provided insights for healthcare professionals that support nurses and, additionally, publicly released a stress detection dataset for use by the research community, and (d) The research effort, “Decision Support Tools for COVID-19” utilized machine learning and big data techniques for both risk assessment and the design of data-driven, COVID 19 mitigation  policies.

CVDI's industry partners have widely recognized and adopted new technologies in big data analytics and decision-making environments resulting from these projects due to their practical implications. The outcomes helped those partners to explore new product and service ideas involving innovative and disruptive methods and technologies, which would have otherwise been prohibitive for them to perform on their own due to limited time and resources. Through the establishment of international collaboration with Tampere University, CVDI projects have provided the highest quality of research exposure for Finnish and US-based researchers and students as it helped to advance their research careers in terms of understanding the global context of industry-relevant, big data research and creating opportunities to network with their peers and build future collaborations.

 


Last Modified: 07/07/2023
Modified by: Raju Gottumukkala
